questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You are designing a storage solution to support on-premises resources and Azure-hosted resources.
You need to provide on-premises storage that has built-in replication to Azure.
Solution: You include Azure Data Lake Storage in the design.
Does the solution meet the goal?

discussion.content: B. No.
B is correct answer.
Data Lake Gen 2 is based on Blob storage; as this is not specified in the question, the answer remains No.

comments.content: You can connect it to your on premise servers

discussion.content:
Q. You need to provide on-premises storage.
How blob storage is on-premises storage?

As Azure Data Lake is based on Azure storage (blob in particular), it is subject to the same SLA at 99.9% and the same range of replication options such as LRS, RA-GRS, etc.
I think correct answer should be YES.

comments.content: But has to be able to replicate to on premises storage which I don't believe is possible with Data Lake
B is ok
Data Lake needs ingestion of biodata and hence the replication from on-prem is not applicable.

discussion.content: B. No.
B is correct answer.
You can not replicate on prem data directly to a table storage, that's why the answer is no
if the previous related answers are yes, this one should be a yes as well as table storage is based on blob storage and supports various redundancy options (LRS, ZRS, GRS, etc)

comments.content: B is ok
Retract my previous answer. Table storage would not be the right solution for replicating on-premise data, so answer is No

discussion.content: Regarding the "Blob Storage" answer, its correct because, even though the requirement is for On-premise storage, the question asked is for the DESIGN. DESIGN includes both parts, the requirement from ON-PREM as well as requirement from Azure, hence the answers Blob and StorSimple have a YES
This is more convincing than Question #39 above, which specifies just Blob storage. For on-premises usage, it has to be StoreSimple.
A. Yes

Check ou the link mentioning that "Store Simple" is out of date by dec-2020. 

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storsimple/storsimple-ova-overview
StorSimple Virtual Array (1200 series) will reach its end-of-life in December 2020. If you are considering new deployments of StorSimple Virtual Array, we recommend that you explore other alternatives such as Azure File Sync or Azure Data Box Online devices for your workloads.
A is correct answer.
given answer is correct
It's the only correct answer in this series, because the question is about on-prem storage.

comments.content: I believe given answer is correct.

https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=2ahUKEwiY9ZrGw-_sAhUHmlkKHQOFA9cQFjANegQIGBAC&url=https%3A%2F%2Fcloudmonix.com%2Fblog%2Fwhat-is-azure-storsimple%2F%23%3A~%3Atext%3DAzure%2520StorSimple%2520is%2520a%2520hybrid%2Cmanaging%2520large%2520quantities%2520of%2520data.&usg=AOvVaw0MsBUQ9ukNond3vldYab6e

discussion.content: there is no device such as Azure StorSimple. It is Storsimple which can backup to azure hence I will go with B.

choices.D: Azure virtual machines that run Microsoft SQL Server servers

discussion.content:
Answer is correct.
Any routes in your virtual network that force internet traffic to your on-premises and/or virtual appliances also force Azure service traffic to take the same route as the internet traffic. Service endpoints provide optimal routing for Azure traffic.
B. virtual network service endpoints
B is correct answer.
B is clearly the answer

comments.content: yeah :D

answer is correct

given ans is correct

comments.content: B is ok

questions.question_text:
You use Azure virtual machines to run a custom application that uses an Azure SQL Database instance on the back end.
The IT department at your company recently enabled forced tunneling.
Since the configuration change, developers have noticed degraded performance when they access the database.
You need to recommend a solution to minimize latency when accessing the database. The solution must minimize costs.
What should you include in the recommendation?

discussion.content:
Answer should be:

A site-to-site VPN: The Azure virtual machine on Subnet1 must be accessible only from the computers in the London Office

A Network Security Group (NSG): Engineers require access to the Azure virtual machines on Subnet2 over the Internet on a specific TCP/IP management port

Virtual Network Peering: The Azure virtual machines in the West Europe region must be able to communicate on all ports to the Azure virtual machines in the North Europe region.

I think that the anser of Site-to-Site and A Network Secuirty Group is correct.
The Azure VM's in the West Europe region must be able to communicate on all ports to the Azure VM's in North Europe Region
⇒Vertual Network Peering is correct
That's from two reasons below
1.The solution must minimize costs and administrative effort whenever possible
2.There is 「Global VNet peering - connecting VNets across Azure regions」
　https://docs.microsoft.com/ja-jp/azure/virtual-network/virtual-network-peering-overview

comments.content: Agree. Thank you!

discussion.content:
The Azue Virtual Machine on subnet1 must be accessible only from Computers in the london office (Answer - Site-to-Site)

Engineers require access to Azure VM's on Subnet2 Over the internet on a specific TCP/IP Management port (Answer- A Network Secuirty Group)

The Azure VM's in the West Europe region must be able to communicate on all ports to the Azure VM's in North Europe Region (Answer- VNet Peering)
https://www.2passeasy.com/dumps/AZ-301-a-14222.html

comments.content: The answer for the 3rd question should be "Global VNET Peering", sadly this is not in the answer options. VNET Peering is different from Global VNET Peering.

discussion.content: In the Exam 12/11/2020

box 3 should be Express Route 

Make your connections fast, reliable, and private
Use Azure ExpressRoute to create private connections between Azure datacenters and infrastructure on your premises or in a colocation environment. ExpressRoute connections don't go over the public Internet, and they offer more reliability, faster speeds, and lower latencies than typical Internet connections. In some cases, using ExpressRoute connections to transfer data between on-premises systems and Azure can give you significant cost benefits.

https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/services/expressroute/#overview

comments.content:
Express route is very expensive, VPN is cheaper, correct solutions:
site to site vpn
NSG
VNet peering

discussion.content: https://vceplus.com/exams/4338/az-301/19603/microsoft-practicetest-az-301-v2019-10-27-by-regina-107q.pdf Question 30

I agree to jcarlos comments. 'ONLY' is the key word which makes me to believe NSG for 1st question
The Azure virtual machines on a subnet named Subnet1 must be accessible only from the computers in your London office.

I am gonna go against the consensus here and say that the answer to the first one should be "A New Vnet" since if subnet1 co-exists with any other subnet, let's say subnet2 in a VNet, subnet2 would be automatically able to access machines in subnet1 unless you add extra inbound rules on subnet1 with higher priority than default rules to block subnet2. Subnet1 needs to be in a separate VNet, connected with London office over a VPN or Express Route.

Second Answer: A NSG

Third Answer: Peering
Global VNet peering available in all the regions

1- Site2Site
2-NSG
3-New Vnet
Global Vnet Peering supports following regions only: 
Europe: UK South (London), UK West (Cardiff), West Europe (Netherlands)
Ref: https://azure.microsoft.com/en-in/updates/region-expansion-global-vnet-peering/

Q1 - A: NSG. You can use either site to site VPN or Expressroute to conect Subnet1 with London office, but none of them will meet the requirement of making the VM in Subnet1 ONLY accessible from London. They will continue being accessible for example from other subnets in the same network unless you use a NSG.
Q2 - A:NSG
Q3 -A: Virtual Network peering

Q and A for this question should be as follow : 

The Azure virtual Machines on Subnet 1 Must be accessible only from the computers in the london Office --> Answer A site to Site VPN 
Engineers Require access to azure virtual machines on Subnet2 over the internet on a specific TCP/IP management port -->Answer : NSG (A Network Security Group)
The Azure VMs in the west Europe region must be able to communicate on all ports to azure VMs in North Europe Region --> Answer : Virtual Network peering
https://issuu.com/ruthgriffithfreedumps/docs/_full-version_2019_braindump2go_new

Virtual network peering: Connect virtual networks within the same Azure region.
 Global virtual network peering: Connecting virtual networks across Azure regions.
... north and west are two different regions. If the option is there I think it would be global.

Site-to-Site VPN
NSG
Vnet-to-Vnet
I agree with the answer lol

“The workloads in the London office on-premise network must only be able to access the Azure virtual machines in the subnet “SubnetA” = a site-to-site VPN

“IT Engineers must be able to connect to Azure virtual machines located in “SubnetB” over a specific TCP port number” = a Network Security Group

“The Azure virtual machines in the West Europe Region must be able to communicate with Azure virtual machines in the North Europe region on all ports” = a Virtual Network peering

a Site-to-Site VPN gateway connection from your on-premises network to the VNet. so this is not correct.

VNet peering - connecting VNets within the same Azure region
Global VNet peering - connecting VNets across Azure regions

so VNet peering is may be the right choice.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-network/virtual-network-peering-overview

comments.content: Express Route is for communication between Client and Azure Cloud . It is not meant to connect Azure regions which can be easily done trough Vnet peering.
first and third answers are reversed.
Also it's asking for a connection method, for "Engineers require access to Azure VM's on Subnet2 Over the internet on a specific TCP/IP Management port" the connection method is a Public IP address.
Not necessary, you can access over TCP/IP port over a FQDN as well. But since port is involved, we need a NSG

From RahulP's answer - The Azure VM's in the West Europe region must be able to communicate on all ports to the Azure VM's in North Europe Region (Answer- An Azure ExpressRoute Connection)

This should be VNet Peering
#3, should be vnet peering , since both ends of desired connection are azure regions..

The Azure VM's in the West Europe region must be able to communicate on all ports to the Azure VM's in North Europe Region - its using Vnet Peering, you don't need ExpressRoute , too complex n expensive and unnecessary

discussion.content:
The Azue Virtual Machine on subnet1 must be accessible only from Computers in the london office (ANswer - Site-to-Site)

Engineers require access to Azure VM's on Subnet2 Over the internet on a specific TCP/IP Management port (Answer- A Network Secuirty Group)

The Azure VM's in the West Europe region must be able to communicate on all ports to the Azure VM's in North Europe Region (Answer- An Azure ExpressRoute Connection)

The Azure VM's in the West Europe region must be able to communicate on all ports to the Azure VM's in North Europe Region (Answer- VNet Peering)

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You are designing a network connectivity strategy for a new Azure subscription. You identify the following requirements:
✑ The Azure virtual machines on a subnet named Subnet1 must be accessible only from the computers in your London office.
✑ Engineers require access to the Azure virtual machine on a subnet named Subnet2 over the Internet on a specific TCP/IP management port.
✑ The Azure virtual machines in the West Europe Azure region must be able to communicate on all ports to the Azure virtual machines in the North Europe Azure region.
You need to recommend which components must be used to meet the requirements. The solution must minimize costs and administrative effort whenever possible.
What should you include in the recommendation? To answer, drag the appropriate components to the correct requirements. Each component may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Select and Place:
